Award.AwardTitle: A novel paradigm for nonlinear convection models and large systems of particles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Jabin
DMS-1614537

Convection or transport mechanisms are a critical feature of several phenomena in physics and the biosciences. This project focuses on such mechanisms in compressible fluid mechanics and systems of many "particles." Compressible fluid mechanics includes a large set of models in very diverse settings: geophysical fluids with gravity in large scale fluids (Earth atmosphere), biological fluids (such as swimming bacteria), or "exotic" examples such as solar events or photon radiation. Systems of particles typically involve a very large number of coupled equations, one for each particle. Particles can here represent many different objects: In physics they can represent ions and electrons in plasmas, or molecules in a fluid, or even galaxies in some cosmological models; in the biosciences particles typically model micro-organisms (cells or bacteria); in economics or social sciences, particles are individual "agents." Instabilities can develop in all those systems and may manifest as oscillations in the mass density of the fluid or as collisions (or near collisions) between particles. A better understanding of such behavior can have important consequences. For example, insights on the swarming motility of micro-organisms would help the development of new biotechnologies. The main challenge to reduce the complexity of such systems is to understand how, and how quickly or slowly, the convection or transport (of mass in the fluid or of the particles) can amplify such oscillations. Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

The project offers a new mathematical framework to study instabilities in many-particles systems and nonlinear convection equations. It unifies the methods to control collisions between particles, required by singular forces, and the ones to propagate regularity in convection equations, required to limit oscillations in nonlinear terms. The new method relies on a direct control of the regularity of the solution through a doubling of variables and requires delicate and explicit commutator estimates. This natural interplay between apparently very different sets of problems leads to new insights and breaks some of the barriers to more realistic models: Systems of interacting particles with physically realistic and unbounded forces or random collisions in velocity, leading to degenerate diffusion; models of fluid mechanics with thermodynamically unstable state laws or anisotropic terms. Graduate students are included in the work of the project.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Maryland College Park, CSCAMM

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project developed new fundamental mathematical tools at the interface of convection mechanisms and so-called multi-agent systems. Convection mechanisms underly a vast array of models in Physics and Bio-physics and the sponsored research focused in particular on:
     -The transport of "particles" which can represent a large variety of objects such as ions and electrons in plasmas, or molecules in a fluid, or even galaxies in some cosmological models; in the Biosciences particles typically model micro-organisms (cells or bacteria); in Economics or Social Sciences, particles are individual ``agents''.
     -Models in Fluid Mechanics such as the widely used Navier-Stokes system, whether for compressible or incompressible flows. The compressible Navier-Stokes is for example used to describe various physical or biophysical settings: Geophysical flows with gravity in large scale fluids, biological flows, flows in porous media where anisotropy is key or ?exotic? examples such as solar events or photon radiation.
Among the main results of the project are:
   -A new statistical approach to describe the distribution of "particles" in large systems. The possibly large number of particles make the study of such systems a priori too complex to be tractable by computational or theoretical tools. The result of the project offered key insights in how to reduce this complexity. A first application had been to the dynamics of vortices in two-dimensional fluid flows through the use of the entropy of the system for the whole probability law of all vortices. An important novel application initiated at the end of the proposal focuses on repulsive interactions, in particular around the so-called Keller-Segel system. This system notably models some "chemotaxis" effects that is the dynamics of micro-organisms under the influence of chemical signals. This extension relies on novel large deviation estimates that measure how much a sum of random numbers deviate from their averages. It also promises to be able to handle strong attractive interactions between micro-organisms. 
   -A novel method to measure oscillations in mathematical systems with convection. This was applied to the compressible Navier-Stokes system with realistic state laws. State laws relate the pressure of a gas to its density and temperature and previous mathematical results all typically assumed that the pressure always increases with pressure. This does not apply to more realistic gases though who may exhibit more complex behaviors.
   -An important application of the research has been devoted to so-called self-propelled swimmers. Those encompass bacterial suspensions but also magnetic rods used to control the flows of fluids in which they are immerged.  Bacterial suspensions are nearly ubiquitous in nature and they also exhibit some fascinating features as the concentration increases. Contrary to other suspensions, bacteria can self-propel injecting kinetic energy in the fluid. This can lead to counter-intuitive behaviors such as a reduction of the fluid's viscosity when the concentration increases.

The project broader impacts have mostly concerned graduate and post-graduate education. Many topics in this project had been designed with the express intent to attract and facilitate students? involvement. This proved quite successful as several young researchers joined the project at various stages, including undergraduates.The sponsored research strongly contributed to community building; first of all by supporting and encouraging students' participation in international conferences and workshops. Special attention has also been given to outreach activities and minorities, with a particular focus again on young investigators.


Last Modified: 08/29/2020
Modified by: Pierre-Emmanuel Jabin

Convection mechanisms underly a vast array of models in Physics and Bio-physics and the sponsored research focused in particular on: -The transport of "particles" which can represent a large variety of objects such as ions and electrons in plasmas, or molecules in a fluid, or even galaxies in some cosmological models; in the Biosciences particles typically model micro-organisms (cells or bacteria); in Economics or Social Sciences, particles are individual ``agents''. -Models in Fluid Mechanics such as the widely used Navier-Stokes system, whether for compressible or incompressible flows. The compressible Navier-Stokes is for example used to describe various physical or biophysical settings: Geophysical flows with gravity in large scale fluids, biological flows, flows in porous media where anisotropy is key or ?exotic? examples such as solar events or photon radiation. Among the main results of the project are: -A new statistical approach to describe the distribution of "particles" in large systems. The possibly large number of particles make the study of such systems a priori too complex to be tractable by computational or theoretical tools. This extension relies on novel large deviation estimates that measure how much a sum of random numbers deviate from their averages. It also promises to be able to handle strong attractive interactions between micro-organisms. -A novel method to measure oscillations in mathematical systems with convection. This was applied to the compressible Navier-Stokes system with realistic state laws. State laws relate the pressure of a gas to its density and temperature and previous mathematical results all typically assumed that the pressure always increases with pressure. This does not apply to more realistic gases though who may exhibit more complex behaviors. -An important application of the research has been devoted to so-called self-propelled swimmers. Those encompass bacterial suspensions but also magnetic rods used to control the flows of fluids in which they are immerged. Bacterial suspensions are nearly ubiquitous in nature and they also exhibit some fascinating features as the concentration increases. Contrary to other suspensions, bacteria can self-propel injecting kinetic energy in the fluid. This can lead to counter-intuitive behaviors such as a reduction of the fluid's viscosity when the concentration increases. The project broader impacts have mostly concerned graduate and post-graduate education. Many topics in this project had been designed with the express intent to attract and facilitate students? involvement. This proved quite successful as several young researchers joined the project at various stages, including undergraduates.The sponsored research strongly contributed to community building; first of all by supporting and encouraging students' participation in international conferences and workshops.
